[h1]A Deep, Satisfying Garage Simulator That Sets the Standard for the Genre[/h1]

Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 is one of the most comprehensive and addictive simulation games available, especially for anyone who loves cars, mechanical tinkering, or hands-on problem solving. Instead of racing or driving, the game puts you firmly in the role of a professional mechanic, diagnosing issues, tearing down engines, replacing parts, painting bodies, and slowly growing your own automotive empire one job at a time.

The level of detail is the game‚Äôs biggest triumph. Every vehicle is built with dozens, sometimes hundreds, of individual parts you can remove, inspect, repair, and reinstall. Engines come apart piece by piece. Suspensions, transmissions, exhausts, electronics, everything is modeled with surprising accuracy. The first time you fully strip a car down to a bare chassis, it‚Äôs hard not to appreciate the craftsmanship behind the system.

[h3]The gameplay loop is incredibly satisfying:[/h3]

- take on a repair job
- inspect and diagnose
- dismantle the right components
- buy or fix replacements
- reassemble the final result

That loop never really gets old because it always feels tactile and rewarding. There‚Äôs something strangely soothing about putting cars back together, tightening bolts, and watching your garage expand with new tools, lifts, and equipment. Progression feels earned, and the sense of improvement, both mechanically and financially is constant.

Visually, Car Mechanic Simulator 2018 punches above its weight. Car models look fantastic, the lighting is clean, and the workshop feels grounded and believable. Sound design is similarly strong, with authentic tool noises and engine sounds giving the garage life. The addition of barn finds, junkyard exploration, auctions, and restoration projects provides even more variety and long-term goals.

That said, the game isn‚Äôt perfect. The grind becomes noticeable in later hours, especially when you‚Äôre saving for major upgrades. Some tasks can feel repetitive, and the UI occasionally requires more clicks than it should. Bugs do appear from time to time, parts not selecting properly, odd physics moments though the experience is far more stable today than it was years ago.

Still, CMS 2018 remains one of the best and most complete mechanic simulators ever made. It‚Äôs relaxing, immersive, and surprisingly educational, offering hundreds of hours of hands-on engagement for anyone who enjoys detailed, methodical work.

[h3]The Good:[/h3]

- Extremely detailed mechanical systems with deeply satisfying hands-on gameplay.
- Huge variety of cars, jobs, upgrades, and restoration activities.
- Strong visuals and sound design that bring the workshop to life.

[h3]The Bad:[/h3]

- Grinding late-game upgrades can feel slow and repetitive.
- UI navigation can be clunky and requires too many clicks.
- Occasional bugs or physics hiccups, especially with certain parts.

[h3]Ratings:[/h3]

[b]Overall:[/b] 9 / 10
[b]Visual:[/b] 9 / 10
[b]Gameplay:[/b] 9 / 10
[b]Story:[/b] 2 / 10
[b]Audio:[/b] 8 / 10
[b]Playability:[/b] 8 / 10

negative.review:
Game is not new player friendly. The "Tutorial" just throws you into the garage without any direction or objectives and expects you to figure out on your own. While looking around, when you look over something that the player is able to interact with, they just pop out a window with a short video of using the thing and a wall of text. It doesn't tell you when you are supposed to use it. The game designer expects you to just remember every single thing that they just threw at you, and you'll just know to use them when the time comes. After going through about 5 or more wall of text, I just gave up as the flow of the "Tutorial" was just annoying me with the constant popping up of windows as soon as i hovered over something while I was trying to explore.

Another major issue is I don't know why you would enable control acceleration at default, that setting made my cursor super sensitive which made it extremely difficult to change my settings when my pointer is flying all over the screen. Also, why can't I access my settings while in game play? I can only change my settings in main menu? I find that design choice baffling.

I live and breath cars but this game sucks. Its so repetitive and time-consuming to do simple tasks. It takes forever to do a single job. Why do I have to spend time taking off every lug nut? Boring... and like I said I'm car lover.

Game is not new player friendly. The "Tutorial" just throws you into the garage without any direction or objectives and expects you to figure out on your own. While looking around, when you look over something that the player is able to interact with, they just pop out a window with a short video of using the thing and a wall of text. It doesn't tell you when you are supposed to use it. The game designer expects you to just remember every single thing that they just threw at you, and you'll just know to use them when the time comes. After going through about 5 or more wall of text, I just gave up as the flow of the "Tutorial" was just annoying me with the constant popping up of windows as soon as i hovered over something while I was trying to explore.

Another major issue is I don't know why you would enable control acceleration at default, that setting made my cursor super sensitive which made it extremely difficult to change my settings when my pointer is flying all over the screen. Also, why can't I access my settings while in game play? I can only change my settings in main menu? I find that design choice baffling.
lack of direction in the games "tutorials" is what makes this bad, I was wondering around for a while all because it didnt say what I had to do to progress

On top of that, you have to save, quit to the main menu, and then re-enter just to access the settings. This game is not worth buying, even on sale. I'm only keeping it installed to farm the trading cards, and I will uninstall it the second the last one drops.
